messageBody:
On Sun, 28 Sep 2003, trz wrote:

> > FWIW I translated the Java into C++ and ran the same benchmark. Oddly
> > enough, the variable name length definitely has a pronounced effect
> > in C++. On a slow PC used as a test box, results looked like this:
> >
> > Java C++ -O1 C++ -O2
> > short 13.4s 3.2s 4.1s
> > long 12.0s 8.4s 7.2s
> >
> > memory use 12.4 MB 0.8 MB 0.8 MB

> with java you have to let the hotspot warm up, running the code several
> times to let the jvm analyze code.

> Run the benchmark for some seconds, than start to measure.

Like hell you do.

When you are benchmarking one thing against another, you don't give one
preferential treatment. You run them under exactly the same conditions.

Now in this case, I was actually being kind to Java. I ignored the
startup time. Had I done "fairer" tests, C++ would have outperformed
Java by a much wider margin.

But the tests were absurdly biased to begin with. They were about as
biased as possible towards removing all of the effects being discussed.

> To have a smaller footprint try -Xms1m.

In the context of the discussion you are replying to, to have a smaller
footprint, run the Java through JAX. This will reduce the code size by
60-70%. That will reduce your load time and memory footprint by a similar
amount and have, I believe, a similar effect on execution time.
